title: 103_hr948
content: Section 1 allows for a deduction for dividends paid by domestic corporations under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a deduction for dividends paid by domestic corporations, excluding certain types of corporations such as S corporations, regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, and personal holding companies. The section discusses the repeal of deductions for dividends received from domestic corporations and rules relating to it, as well as special rules for certain distributions of mutual savings banks. Deductions for dividends paid on certain preferred stock of public utilities are also repealed. Conforming amendments are made regarding dividends received from certain foreign corporations. The amendment to section 245(a) of the Code removes the specified percentage for dividends received from 10-percent owned foreign corporations and replaces it with the applicable percentage determined under paragraph (12). The applicable percentage is 100 percent for dividends received. The amendment to section 245(a) of the Code sets different applicable percentages for dividends received based on the source: 100 percent for dividends from small business investment companies, 80 percent for dividends from a 20-percent owned corporation, and 70 percent for any other dividends. A 20-percent owned corporation is defined as a corporation where the taxpayer owns 20 percent or more of the stock. The amendment to section 245 of the Code introduces new subsections regarding the limitation on the aggregate amount of dividends received deduction and special rules. The amendment to section 245 of the Code introduces new subsections limiting deductions based on taxable income without certain deductions and adjustments, with special rules for net operating losses. The amendment to section 245 of the Code introduces new subsections limiting deductions based on taxable income without certain deductions and adjustments, with special rules for net operating losses. Subparagraph (A) applies separately to dividends from 20-percent owned corporations, with a 80 percent percentage, and then to dividends not from 20-percent owned corporations with a 70 percent percentage. No deduction is allowed for certain dividends under subsection (a) or (b). The amendment to section 245 of the Code limits deductions for certain dividends under subsection (a) or (b) based on holding period rules. For shares held for 45 days or less, no deduction is allowed, and for certain preference dividends, the holding period is extended to 90 days instead of 45 days. The holding period for certain dividends under section 245 of the Code is extended to 90 days if the taxpayer receives dividends attributable to a period exceeding 366 days. Holding periods are determined by excluding the day of acquisition and considering the day of disposition, as well as not counting days more than 45 days (or 90 days for specific stock) after the ex-dividend date. The holding period for dividends under section 245 of the Code is extended to 90 days if the taxpayer receives dividends for a period exceeding 366 days. Holding periods are adjusted for certain situations like options to sell or short sales of identical stock. The taxpayer's risk of loss can be reduced by holding other positions related to similar property. This does not apply to qualified covered calls. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to deductions for dividends received from certain foreign corporations and the reduction of dividends received deduction where portfolio stock is debt financed. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to the dividends received deduction for small business investment companies and mutual savings banks. Sections 243, 244, and 246 are amended, and limitations on the deduction are specified. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for part VIII of subchapter B of chapter 1. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to the dividends received deduction for small business investment companies and mutual savings banks. The deduction amount is limited based on the taxable year, with a gradual increase from 50% to 100% starting from July 1, 1993. Additionally, there is a reduction in capital gains tax. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to set a maximum capital gains rate based on qualified net capital gain for taxpayers. The tax imposed shall not exceed a certain percentage of the net gain over different time periods. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to establish a maximum capital gains rate based on qualified net capital gain for taxpayers. The tax imposed shall not exceed a certain percentage of the net gain over different time periods, including gains from assets held for more than 3 years. The tax code establishes a maximum capital gains rate based on qualified net capital gain for taxpayers. It limits the tax on gains from assets held for specific time periods, including 3-to-6 year net gain and 6-to-9 year net gain. Other definitions for longer holding periods are determined similarly. The tax code sets a maximum capital gains rate based on qualified net capital gain. If the highest tax rate exceeds 28 percent, the excess tax on net capital gain is limited to 28 percent. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1991. The tax code is amended to restore the investment tax credit for property with a long useful life, specifically adding a manufacturing equipment credit. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1991. The tax code amendment introduces a manufacturing equipment credit of 10% of the amortizable basis for property used in manufacturing, production, or extraction by a domestic manufacturing company. The credit applies to property with a class life exceeding 24 months and not classified as public utility property. The credit phases out to 7.5% after December 31, 1993. The amendment introduces a manufacturing equipment credit of 7.5% of the amortizable basis for property used in manufacturing, effective from January 1, 1993, through December 31, 1996.
